docs.snippet: After the Fall  The sound of hammers chipping at concrete greets visitors to the latest show at the Museum of Modern Art in Stockholm. It is the recorded sound of the hundreds of people who demolished the Berlin Wall in 1989, and it is the introdu...
docs.lead_paragraph: After the Fall The sound of hammers chipping at concrete greets visitors to the latest show at the Museum of Modern Art in Stockholm. It is the recorded sound of the hundreds of people who demolished the Berlin Wall in 1989, and it is the introduction to an exhibition that illuminates the work of artists from the former Soviet bloc since the fall of Communism. Continuing through Jan. 16, the exhibition, ''After the Wall,'' at the Moderna Museet, assembles works by 140 artists from 22 countries. By the Bay The premiere of ''Dead Man Walking,'' based on the book by Sister Helen Prejean, will be a highlight of the 78th season of the San Francisco Opera. The season, beginning on Sept. 8 and ending on July 1, 2001, will consist of 82 performances of 11 operas. ''Dead Man Walking,'' with music by Jake Heggie and libretto by Terrence McNally, will play seven performances from Oct. 7 to 28. Company premieres include ''The Czar's Bride'' by Rimsky-Korsakov, ''Semele'' by Handel, and ''Simon Boccanegra'' by Verdi. New productions include Verdi's ''Luisa Miller'' and Douglas Moore's ''Ballad of Baby Doe.''
docs.abstract: Museum of Modern Art in Stockholm, Sweden, mounts exhibit of work of artists from former Soviet bloc since fall of Communism; San Francisco Opera will open 78th season with premier of Dead Man Walking, with music by Jake Heggie and libretto by Terrence McNally, based on book by Sister Helen Prejean; Kansai Youth Symphony of Japan will perform Beethoven's Ninth Symphony at Carnegie Hall; new museum in Rome, Papal Stables at Quirinale Palace, will exhibit 80 paintings on loan from Hermitage Museum in Russia; photos (M)
